#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=5. Discussion
#Text=5.1. General Issues
#Text=The data showed sediment movement within the channels over time .
#Text=The survey lines showed both deposition and erosion at different locations on various lines .

#Text=In some cases , the changes did not appear to be from the result of physical processes , but were either the results of data collection errors , such as not surveying the identical location , or issues relating to the analysis .
#Text=The following sections describe trends within the channels for each survey line .

#Text=In these discussions we explain the observed trends or changes and attempt to associate these trends with physical processes or attribute the changes to other issues ; however , these explanations may not accurately represent what is actually happening due to the limited amount of data .

#Text=While enough data were collected to determine if this approach is feasible , there were not sufficient data collected to adequately characterize all the various processes occurring in the channels , which was not an objective of this study .
#Text=The sonar data matched our expectations and what we know of the physical delta recutting that occurs at DCR .
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=shows two channels in the exposed DCR sediment delta taken when the reservoir was significantly drawn down for dam repair .
#Text=The left panel of
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=shows sharp slopes resembles sonar geometry in the results from Lines 4 to 7 which show channels with sharp side slopes that are almost vertical ( sonar results are shown later in
#Text=Figure 7
#Text=,
#Text=Figure 8
#Text=,
#Text=Figure 9
#Text=and
#Text=Figure 10
#Text=) .
#Text=These results closely matched channel shapes in the exposed delta area shown in the left panel of
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=.
#Text=The right panel of
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=, from the same time period , shows a more rounded channel , similar sonar-delimited channels that appear in Lines 1 to 4 ( sonar results are shown later in
#Text=Figure 7
#Text=and
#Text=Figure 8
#Text=) .
#Text=The data for all the lines showed that as the distance along the survey line increases , there is more apparent change in the sediment .
#Text=That is , it appears that there is more sediment movement occurring at the end of the line than near the beginning .
#Text=This occurs even in areas between the channels where we expected no , or little , change .

#Text=Both the nature of these differences , increasing with increasing distance along the line , and changes occurring in regions we expect to have no or little change indicate that these changes were a result of a problem with our measurement or processing methods .
#Text=These changes were not large , but were noticeable .

#Text=We determined that the most likely cause of these anomalies was the processing step where we converted the latitude and longitude readings ( x and y data ) , to one-dimensional data representing distance along a line .
#Text=In our method we used the starting coordinate of the survey line as the initial point and we computed distance along the line as the distance from this point .

#Text=However , during field data collections , it was extremely rare ( i.e. , never ) for the survey line to be perfectly straight during collection , as the boat occasionally moved slightly off the heading and was brought back on line .
#Text=Thus the distance from the line origin to a sample point was not necessarily the distance along the line .

#Text=One potential way to address this issue would be to not to compute the distance between the line origin and a measured point , but to create a rotated coordinate system for each line with one ordinal direction matched to the line direction .
#Text=Then the converted data would show distance from the starting point along the line ( on-track distance ) and the perpendicular distance of the point ( off-track distance ) from the line .
#Text=This would have the added benefit of easier identification of measured points significantly off the survey line .
#Text=This was an error in our method .
#Text=5.2. Discussion
#Text=Survey Lines 1 , 2 , and 3
#Text=Lines 1 , 2 , and 3 (
#Text=Figure 7
#Text=) , were only surveyed two times on 2 July and 16 July and because of reservoir drawdown this area was too shallow to access on the other trips .
#Text=The data for these lines showed little change over this two-week period , but the data indicated several potential survey problems and small changes would not be evident .

#Text=As these were to first two surveys , it is likely that there may have been problems with the sonar setup , as the sonar requires accurate off-set and other information that may have been entered incorrectly .
#Text=Because we could not access these lines in subsequent surveys , we could not determine the cause or causes of the anomalies present in the data .
